aia_level_1:
The Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA), led from the Lockheed Martin Solar and Astrophysics Laboratory (LMSAL), provides continuous full-disk observations of the solar chromosphere and corona in seven extreme ultraviolet (EUV) channels, spanning a temperature range from approximately 20,000 Kelvin to in excess of 20 million Kelvin.

It takes images at a 12-second cadence with a resolution of 4096 by 4096 pixels and 0.6 arcsec/pixel.
aia_level_1.5:
The Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA), led from the Lockheed Martin Solar and Astrophysics Laboratory (LMSAL), provides continuous full-disk observations of the solar chromosphere and corona in seven extreme ultraviolet (EUV) channels, spanning a temperature range from approximately 20,000 Kelvin to in excess of 20 million Kelvin.

It takes images at a 12-second cadence with a resolution of 4096 by 4096 pixels and 0.6 arcsec/pixel.
aia_level_2:
The Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA), led from the Lockheed Martin Solar and Astrophysics Laboratory (LMSAL), provides continuous full-disk observations of the solar chromosphere and corona in seven extreme ultraviolet (EUV) channels, spanning a temperature range from approximately 20,000 Kelvin to in excess of 20 million Kelvin.

It takes images at a 12-second cadence with a resolution of 4096 by 4096 pixels and 0.6 arcsec/pixel.
chrotel_level_1: Chromospheric Telescope at the Observatorio del Teide on Tenerife
eit_level_0:
The Extreme ultraviolet Imaging Telescope (EIT) is an instrument on the SOHO spacecraft used to obtain high-resolution images of the solar corona in the ultraviolet range.

The EIT instrument is sensitive to light of four different wavelengths: 17.1, 19.5, 28.4, and 30.4 nm, corresponding to light produced by highly ionized iron (XI)/(X), (XII), (XV), and helium (II), respectively
eit_synoptic:
The Extreme ultraviolet Imaging Telescope (EIT) is an instrument on the SOHO spacecraft used to obtain high-resolution images of the solar corona in the ultraviolet range.

The EIT instrument is sensitive to light of four different wavelengths: 17.1, 19.5, 28.4, and 30.4 nm, corresponding to light produced by highly ionized iron (XI)/(X), (XII), (XV), and helium (II), respectively
eui_level_1: The Extreme Ultraviolet Imager (EUI) is part of the remote sensing instrument package of the ESA/NASA Solar Orbiter mission
eui_level_2: The Extreme Ultraviolet Imager (EUI) is part of the remote sensing instrument package of the ESA/NASA Solar Orbiter mission
euvi_level_0: The Extreme Ultraviolet Imager observes the chromosphere and low corona in four different EUV emission lines between 17.1 and 30.4 nm
gaia_dem:
The Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA), led from the Lockheed Martin Solar and Astrophysics Laboratory (LMSAL), provides continuous full-disk observations of the solar chromosphere and corona in seven extreme ultraviolet (EUV) channels, spanning a temperature range from approximately 20,000 Kelvin to in excess of 20 million Kelvin.

It takes images at a 12-second cadence with a resolution of 4096 by 4096 pixels and 0.6 arcsec/pixel.
gris_level_1: GRIS (GREGOR Infrared Spectrograph), the grating spectrograph installed in the recently inaugurated (May 2012) 1.5-meter GREGOR telescope located at the Observatorio del Teide in Tenerife
hmi_magnetogram: The Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager (HMI), led from Stanford University in Stanford, California, take high-resolution measurements of the longitudinal and vector magnetic field over the entire visible solar disk.
hmi_magnetogram_level_1.5: The Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager (HMI), led from Stanford University in Stanford, California, take high-resolution measurements of the longitudinal and vector magnetic field over the entire visible solar disk.
ibis: The Interferometric Bidimensional Spectrometer (IBIS, Cavallini 2006) is a post-focus instrument for solar bi-dimensional spectro-polarimetry
lars_level_1: The Laser Absolute Reference Spectrograph is a high-resolution echelle spectrograph capable of providing absolutely calibrated solar spectra in the visible 480nm to 750nm range
lyra_level_2: LYRA (Large Yield RAdiometer) is a middle-to-extreme ultraviolet radiometer that observes the Sun in four broad passbands, chosen for their relevance to solar physics, aeronomy and space weather
lyra_level_3: LYRA (Large Yield RAdiometer) is a middle-to-extreme ultraviolet radiometer that observes the Sun in four broad passbands, chosen for their relevance to solar physics, aeronomy and space weather
rosa: ROSA is a high cadence, high efficiency solar imager which is installed as a common-user instrument on the Dunn Solar Telescope at the National Solar Observatory in New Mexico, USA
swap_level_1:
The "Sun Watcher using Active Pixel System Detector and Image Processing" (SWAP) telescope is a compact EUV imager on board the PROBA2 mission that  observes the Sun in extreme ultraviolet (EUV, 17.4 nm).

SWAP provides images of the solar corona at a temperature of roughly 1 million degrees
uset_calciumii-k_level_1: The USET CalciumII-K instrument consists of a 13.2 cm William Optics refractor
uset_h-alpha_level_1: The USET H-alpha refractor is a 8 cm aperture Celestron
uset_white_light_level_1:
The USET White Light refractor consists of a 15 cm aperture Lichtenknecker doublet.
  Its wide-band filter peaks at wavelength 510 nm with a band-pass of 158 nm.
  From 2002 till 2008, it was equipped with a 1024x1024 CCD, and since 2008, with a Retiga CCDwith 2048x2048 pixels.
xrt_level_1:
X-ray Telescope
A modified Wolter I telescope design that uses grazing incidence optics to image the solar corona's hottest components (0.5 to 10 Million K) with an angular resolution consistent with 1 arcsec pixels at the CCD
